meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

You already learned 外す, which is used when YOU remove something. 外れる, on the other hand means <vocabulary>to come off</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be off</vocabulary>. It's used when something ends up outside of where it's supposed to be — like a plug coming out of a socket. 

To remember the difference with 外す, just think of how <reading>rare</reading> (れる) it is for a plug to come out on its own, compared to when you intentionally remove it. It's kind of rare, right?

More figuratively, 外れる can also describe when your expectations are off — the results have ended up "outside" of what you were hoping for.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

直り is the noun form of 直る, which you already know means "to be fixed." When a <kanji>relationship</kanji> is fixed, you get <vocabulary>reconciliation</vocabulary>. In other words, you're <vocabulary>making peace</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>making up</vocabulary> with someone. Good on you.
This is a single kanji with しい on the end, so you know it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>sad</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>sad</vocabulary>, sadly.

The <kanji>five</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji>s that you have are what? Sight, sound, taste, touch, and smell (don't count the sixth one where you see dead people). These are <vocabulary>the five senses</vocabulary> that you probably have.
When you're <kanji>request</kanji>ing <kanji>people</kanji>, you put up a <vocabulary>job posting</vocabulary> because you’re <vocabulary>seeking workers</vocabulary>.

You have <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>flat objects</kanji> that make up your <kanji>tongue</kanji>. What kind of tongue is made up of two of anything? That's a tongue that's split, that's a <vocabulary>forked tongue</vocabulary>.

The kanji means <kanji>riot</kanji>, but this verb version word doesn't really mean "to riot." It's more like <vocabulary>to be in disorder</vocabulary>. But if you think about it, when things are rioting and crazy, they definitely are in disorder, so you can think of it that way. You can differentiate this from the future word 乱す because with れる you know it is <reading>rare</reading> for it to be like this. You aren't doing it, but it just happens on occasion (rarely) so you take advantage of it.

A <kanji>riot</kanji> of <kanji>war</kanji> is where things go nuts. This is a <vocabulary>melee</vocabulary>!

乱戦 refers to a <vocabulary>chaotic battle</vocabulary>. It can describe actual warfare, sports matches, or other competitive scenarios where things become tumultuous and disorganized.
There's a <kanji>riot</kanji> and everything's getting all <kanji>mix</kanji>ed up! Within that, there is of course a ton of <vocabulary>confusion</vocabulary>.

A big <kanji>mix</kanji> of folks forming a kind of <kanji>riot</kanji>. You'd think this would be something more violent, but it's really just an <vocabulary>orgy</vocabulary>. Lots of mixing, I guess, and not very much organization on the orgy-organizer's part, at least according to this kanji sequence.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
<kanji>Three</kanji> <kanji>books</kanji> equals <vocabulary>three books</vocabulary>.
When you have <kanji>eight</kanji> <kanji>books</kanji> you have <vocabulary>eight books</vocabulary>. This is an example of how to count books, so if you have eight of them this is what you'd say.
When you have <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>books</kanji> you really just have <vocabulary>one book</vocabulary>.
Usually you call <kanji>books</kanji> "volumes" when they come in sets, right? This is like that, but <kanji>separate</kanji>, making this a <vocabulary>separate volume</vocabulary>.

You <kanji>add</kanji> and you <kanji>subtract</kanji>. This brings you back to zero. There was absolutely no point in doing those actions. Completely <vocabulary>pointless</vocabulary>. In fact, I'd say that was downright <vocabulary>irresponsible</vocabulary> of you. The extra いい is there to mean "good," as in "good, you've figured out how pointless that was, now stop."
The <kanji>power</kanji> of the <kanji>atom</kanji> (原子) is <vocabulary>nuclear power</vocabulary>.
When you <kanji>renew</kanji> something and it ends up <kanji>morally good</kanji> it's definitely an <vocabulary>improvement</vocabulary>.
You have <kanji>morally good</kanji> and <kanji>bad</kanji>. This is the battle between <vocabulary>good and evil</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>group</kanji> that has <kanji>collect</kanji>ed together is a bunch of people. It is a <vocabulary>group</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crowd</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>enter</kanji> a <kanji>group</kanji>, it's called <vocabulary>enrollment</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>enlistment</vocabulary>. You're <vocabulary>joining</vocabulary> the group.
The <kanji>seasons</kanji> <kanji>season</kanji> is the <vocabulary>season</vocabulary>. Who likes winter? It's my favorite 季節.

The <kanji>midair</kanji> of <kanji>outer space</kanji> is the space that's in outer space which is <vocabulary>outer space</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>space</vocabulary>, and the <vocabulary>universe</vocabulary>!

You know how 警察 is "police"? Well, this is kind of like that. This time you have someone from the <kanji>government</kanji> trying to <kanji>warn</kanji> you about the bad things you do. This person, like 警察 is a <vocabulary>police officer</vocabulary>. It's kind of informal, so you might also say this means <vocabulary>cop</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Inside</kanji> that <kanji>form</kanji>... there is something inside there. What are the <vocabulary>contents</vocabulary>?
You have the <kanji>appearance</kanji> of <kanji>doubt</kanji> about you. That's because you're under <vocabulary>suspicion</vocabulary>. There's a <vocabulary>charge</vocabulary> against you. Oh no!

A <kanji>part of speech</kanji> that creates the <kanji>shape</kanji> and <kanji>form</kanji> of a word is something that is descriptive (its shape and form are in there, after all!). This shape and form part of speech is an <vocabulary>adjective</vocabulary>. You are so beautiful!

Think about all the important places your <kanji>footwear</kanji> has touched, one place to the next in <kanji>continuation</kanji>, and <kanji>write</kanji> it all down. What you'd get is a <vocabulary>personal history</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>resume</vocabulary>. I guess you can think of it as a history of the schools and jobs you've left your footprints at.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>footwear</kanji>. And what do you do with footwear, usually? You put it on! That's why this word is <vocabulary>to put on shoes</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put on pants</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put on a skirt</vocabulary>.

Okay, pants and skirts aren't exactly footwear. But 履く is basically used for any garment you wear from the waist down, including socks, shoes, boots, pants, skirts, shorts, and even underpants.

A <kanji>young</kanji> <kanji>cloth</kanji> for some reason is the seaweed <vocabulary>wakame</vocabulary>. If you've never heard of wakame before, go look it up. It's delicious and really good for you. Seaweed is kind of like cloth in the sea, right? Well, this young cloth is nice and soft and thin, like wakame. I imagine young people are soft and thin too, which is why the young cloth gets to be wakame.

Note that this word is more commonly written in kana, like わかめ or ワカメ.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Your <kanji>wealth</kanji> <kanji>cloth</kanji> is your <vocabulary>wallet</vocabulary>. Really, a wallet is just a piece of cloth you keep in your pocket that has your wealth in it, right? This can also be your <vocabulary>purse</vocabulary>, especially if you live in the ol' UK.

Put some <kanji>cloth</kanji> in a <kanji>group</kanji> and you get a <vocabulary>futon</vocabulary>. It’s just the kind of nice, soft <vocabulary>bedding</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sleeping mat</vocabulary> you’d like to curl up on.

Keep in mind that this word is different from the English version. We’re not talking about sofa-beds for your dorm room here. In Japanese, your 布団 is the traditional bedding you lay out on the floor at night and put away in the daytime. 布団 can refer to the sleeping mat, the <vocabulary>duvet</vocabulary> that covers it, or both items as a set.

A <kanji>fur</kanji> <kanji>cloth</kanji> isn't something you'd just throw away. You'd probably turn this warm fur cloth into a nice <vocabulary>blanket</vocabulary>.

毛布 usually refers specifically to a <vocabulary>wool blanket</vocabulary>, as opposed to comforters for example.

One who is <kanji>junior</kanji> in <kanji>life</kanji> is a <vocabulary>student</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pupil</vocabulary>. It's kind of like how a 先生 is someone who came previous to you in life. Cool how that works, right? Okay 生徒, get back to work!
You know 仏教 means “Buddhism” so a <kanji>follower</kanji> of Buddhism is a <vocabulary>Buddhist</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>junior</kanji> <kanji>believe</kanji>r is a <vocabulary>believer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>follower</vocabulary>. They certainly aren't the leader or anything because of their junior status, but at least they're there, and at least they're believing. Oh, and excuse me, may I take a moment of your time? I'd like to tell you about the glory that is the Crabigator....

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>acquire</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to acquire</vocabulary>.

When you are able to <kanji>acquire</kanji> whatever you want, you start to see the <vocabulary>benefit</vocabulary>s of everything around you and begin to <vocabulary>profit</vocabulary> from them. Aren't you so amazing?

When you're able to <kanji>acquire</kanji> <kanji>idea</kanji>s at a fast rate, you must be familiar with whatever it is you're doing. If you acquire ideas in this way, there's a good chance you're <vocabulary>good at</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>skilled at</vocabulary> this action.

You <kanji>acquire</kanji> <kanji>theory</kanji> after theory. In doing this, you have a lot of theories in your head. You use all these theories as tools for <vocabulary>persuasion</vocabulary>. These theories will allow you to <vocabulary>convince</vocabulary> anyone of anything.
This is a single kanji with しい on the end, meaning it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>busy</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>busy</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>person</kanji> of <kanji>romance</kanji> is someone you do romancey things with. That person is your <vocabulary>lover</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Renew</kanji> and make something <kanji>correct</kanji>. When you do this, you are doing a <vocabulary>revision</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>amendment</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>alteration</vocabulary>. Ah, much better now.
You know how 失敗 is a mistake? Well, a <kanji>large</kanji> <kanji>mistake</kanji> is going to be a <vocabulary>total failure</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>huge mistake</vocabulary>. So terrible!

<kanji>Insect</kanji> <kanji>cloth</kanji> is actually <vocabulary>konbu</vocabulary>. <vocabulary>Konbu seaweed</vocabulary> is very common in Japan, and it's delicious. And insects happen to love using it as cloth, too. They make all their clothes out of konbu.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>easy</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>easy</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>form</kanji> in front of you is <kanji>easy</kanji>. Whatever it is, you'll be able to do it with <vocabulary>ease</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>violence</kanji>. "To violence" doesn't sound great, so instead this word is <vocabulary>to act violently</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to rage</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>power</kanji> of <kanji>violence</kanji> is more <vocabulary>violence</vocabulary>, and it is a <vocabulary>force</vocabulary> to be reckoned with.

<kanji>Riot</kanji> and <kanji>violence</kanji>. That sounds terrible! That sounds like a place full of violence, because rioting is <vocabulary>violent</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>violence</vocabulary> is violent too!

<kanji>Violent</kanji> <kanji>running</kanji>... sounds like a marathon gone wrong. No, this is when you run around and you're all violent. A better way to describe this would be to say "<vocabulary>run wild</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>run out of control</vocabulary>."

You know 梅 is a Japanese plum, and 干す means "to dry something." So when you combine them as 梅干し, you get dried plums, right? Well, sort of. You have to pickle them before you dry them, so we can say 梅干し means <vocabulary>pickled plum</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pickled ume</vocabulary>. And if you know the Japanese name, you can call it by that too: <vocabulary>umeboshi</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>continuation</kanji> of <kanji>history</kanji> is <vocabulary>history</vocabulary> itself. This is the main word for "history" and you'll see it a lot if you're in school or something.
A <kanji>continuation</kanji> of <kanji>study</kanji>ing is the time that passes that we study. This is <vocabulary>academic history</vocabulary>, so pay close attention!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>mix</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to mix something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to stir something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to blend something</vocabulary>. 

This is when someone is actively doing the mixing. You can remember this because <reading>they're</reading> (ぜる) doing the mixing themselves, rather than just sitting around and waiting for something to naturally mix on its own.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>decrease</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to decrease</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be decreased</vocabulary>.
What's a <kanji>method</kanji> to <kanji>decrease</kanji> something? Well, you take something away. You do <vocabulary>subtraction</vocabulary>.

Think of what a <kanji>paragraph</kanji> of a <kanji>season</kanji> would be. It's a small part of the season, but it's worth writing about. That's a <vocabulary>seasonal festival</vocabulary>. These are fun!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>entangle</kanji>, but this verb version is usually used in a figurative sense, so it means <vocabulary>to be involved with</vocabulary>, as in 事件に絡む (to be involved with an incident).

絡む can still describe something thread-like winding around something else though, like ツタが木に絡む (the ivy twines around the tree), so it also means <vocabulary>to get tangled</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to entwine</vocabulary>. Note that this use is still intransitive because it focuses on the state of things being entwined, and に marks the location of the action, not a direct object.

To remember that this is intransitive, imagine suddenly hearing a lot of <reading>moo</reading>ing (む) and turning around to find that your cows have somehow gotten entangled. They're all just suddenly in a knot. HOW??

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>continue</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to continue</vocabulary>. Please continue.

When you <kanji>continue</kanji> and then you <kanji>continue</kanji> again (that's the <kanji>repeater</kanji> kanji), you get things happening <vocabulary>one after another</vocabulary>. Continue continue continue!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>cat</kanji>'s <kanji>tongue</kanji> is for some reason associated with an <vocabulary>aversion to hot foods</vocabulary>. I guess I haven't seen a cat drinking up boiling milk, but whatever. Just imagine a cat licking up something super hot and freaking out. Cats don't like hot things, which is why this is an aversion to hot foods.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>young</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>young</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>young</kanji> <kanji>someone</kanji> is a <vocabulary>young person</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>young</kanji> <kanji>young</kanji> thing has <vocabulary>youthful</vocabulary>ness on their side. Oh to be youthful and <vocabulary>young looking</vocabulary> again!
A <kanji>name</kanji> <kanji>part of speech</kanji> is when you are naming something. What part of speech has names in it? That would be the <vocabulary>noun</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>part of speech</kanji> that represents <kanji>moving</kanji> is a part of speech that describes actions. That is a <vocabulary>verb</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>song</kanji>'s <kanji>part of speech</kanji> is the part of the song where you're talking (aka singing). These are the word parts of the song. These are the <vocabulary>song lyrics</vocabulary>. Anyone ready for some カラオケ?

A <kanji>part of speech</kanji> that's just meant to <kanji>help</kanji> your grammar out are the little things. They tie grammar and words together, and that's about it. These are <vocabulary>grammar particle</vocabulary>s or just plain old <vocabulary>particle</vocabulary>s.
A <kanji>number</kanji> <kanji>part of speech</kanji> is a <vocabulary>numeral</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>number word</vocabulary>.

Remember how 動詞 means "verb"? When the verb's action happens by itself or to the subject itself, it's an intransitive verb. In other words, it doesn't need a direct object to complete its action. These are verbs like 行く or 着く or 消える. They're doing something, but they're not doing it to anyone or anything. Can you think of other 自動詞 in Japanese?
Know how 意識 is "consciousness"? What about when this <kanji>consciousness</kanji> doesn't exist (aka it is <kanji>nothing</kanji>)? That's when it becomes <vocabulary>unconsciousness</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Private</kanji> <kanji>wealth</kanji> are <vocabulary>private funds</vocabulary> or your <vocabulary>own funds</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>wealth</kanji> you <kanji>borrow</kanji> is your <vocabulary>debt</vocabulary>.

If you <kanji>take along</kanji> and <kanji>continue</kanji> something, you are creating a <vocabulary>serial</vocabulary> version of it. Come along now. Okay, continue! Come along now. Okay, continue! This is how Lord of the Rings was made, probably. Come along now.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>take along</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary> to take along</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>wealth</kanji> <kanji>clan</kanji> is a group of people who do whatever they can to get their money. These are the <vocabulary>plutocrats</vocabulary> of the world, but you can also call them a <vocabulary>financial clique</vocabulary>.

財閥, or the <vocabulary>zaibatsu</vocabulary>, were large family-controlled conglomerates prominent in Japan until the end of World War II. Some, like Mitsubishi, survive in modernized form. You might see zaibatsu mentioned in books on Japanese history or economics.

When something is moving towards <kanji>emergency</kanji> (非常), it is something that is <vocabulary>very</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>extremely</vocabulary> bad. Like, <vocabulary>exceedingly</vocabulary> so. It's nuts.

You know how 非常 means <kanji>emergency</kanji> and how 口 can be some kind of doorway (like in 入り口, for example)? Well, if that's the case, then you have an emergency doorway. Usually you run away from emergencies, though, making this an <vocabulary>emergency exit</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>order</kanji> that you are <kanji>rank</kanji>ed in is your <vocabulary>ranking</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>standing</vocabulary> amongst others on a list. Beat that high score, Ryu!
When you go in <kanji>order</kanji> of <kanji>turn</kanji>s that's the <vocabulary>order</vocabulary>. It also represents <vocabulary>one's turn</vocabulary> in said order as well.
When the <kanji>order</kanji> is from <kanji>big</kanji> (to small), you are talking about <vocabulary>decreasing order</vocabulary>. That's <vocabulary>largest first</vocabulary>.
When something goes from <kanji>small</kanji> and goes in <kanji>order</kanji> it's in <vocabulary>increasing order</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>smallest first</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>order</kanji> of <kanji>seat</kanji>s is the <vocabulary>seating order</vocabulary>. Everyone go sit in your proper positions, please.
You put <kanji>year</kanji>s in <kanji>order</kanji> of the <kanji>period</kanji> they come in and you're really putting them in <vocabulary>chronological order</vocabulary>.

This is a little confusing for someone who didn't grow up with the Japanese language. You have <kanji>fifty</kanji> <kanji>sound</kanji>s. Then, they're in a certain <kanji>order</kanji>. So, these fifty sounds are the Japanese syllabary. That's hiragana / katakana, probably from back in the day when there were more sounds than there are now. So, the "fifty sounds in order" makes up <vocabulary>aiueo order</vocabulary>, where the "aiueo" is あいうえお representing the five columns.

So this doesn't really make much sense in terms of the kanji and word, but it is what it is. Let's remember it this way:

The kanji is <kanji>fruit</kanji> so the meaning is <vocabulary>really</vocabulary>? Like, really really? Because it sounds like you made that up. I really doubt it means really.

It can also mean <vocabulary>as was expected</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>just as I thought</vocabulary>, but usually we use it as a way to say, "Really? I don't really believe you..."

This is an adjective utilizing the second meaning of 細, <kanji>detailed</kanji>. So, this just means <vocabulary>detailed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>fine</vocabulary>!

You can remember that this one is "detailed" or "fine" because the かい makes you think of <reading>coy</reading>otes. Your hobby is making extremely detailed and fine model railroads out of nothing but raw meat. This, however, means that coyotes regularly come in and destroy all of your fine handiwork.
A <kanji>government office</kanji> for police (警察) is a <vocabulary>police station</vocabulary>, because that's where they hang out, right?
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>steam</kanji> <kanji>flute</kanji> is a flute that goes off using steam. The only time I can think of this happening is via a <vocabulary>steam whistle</vocabulary>. Choo choooo!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>add</kanji> and this word is the verb version of that: <vocabulary>to add</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning that you are doing the adding to something else. You add a nose to your snowman, for example.
When you <kanji>participate</kanji>, <kanji>add</kanji>ing yourself to the activity, that is <vocabulary>participation</vocabulary>. Well done, you earn a gold star for participating!
You <kanji>take along</kanji> a message and <kanji>entangle</kanji> it into the telephone. From there it buzzes off to the person in order for you <vocabulary>to contact</vocabulary> them.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

<kanji>Bake</kanji>d <kanji>potato</kanji> is actually <vocabulary>baked sweet potato</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>roasted sweet potato</vocabulary>). Although it's literally just potato, most Japanese speakers will automatically think of sweet potato when they hear this word. Yum! 🍠
A じゃが <kanji>potato</kanji> is a <vocabulary>potato</vocabulary>. More specifically, a <vocabulary>white potato</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>drama</kanji> <kanji>group</kanji> is a <vocabulary>drama troupe</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>theatrical company</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bury</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to bury</vocabulary> as well.

埋める can also mean <vocabulary>to fill</vocabulary>, and can refer to filling a hole, vacancy, or gap. Note that this word can be used to refer to filling in figurative holes and gaps too, like a hole in one’s finances!
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>small animal</kanji> is <vocabulary>one small animal</vocabulary>. Use this to count small animals like cats and dogs.
A <kanji>product</kanji> of <kanji>part of speech</kanji> is more <vocabulary>part of speech</vocabulary>. Evil begets evil, so to speak.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>memorize</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to memorize</vocabulary>. That shouldn't be too hard <vocabulary>to remember</vocabulary>, right?

People you want to <kanji>take along</kanji> to the <kanji>middle</kanji> of somewhere are probably people you know pretty well. They're your <vocabulary>gang</vocabulary>, they're the <vocabulary>guys</vocabulary>.

This word often has a negative feel to it, though, as in "those guys can't be trusted" or "they're a selfish bunch".
If you've had <kanji>many</kanji> <kanji>busy</kanji> days, then you're even more <vocabulary>busy</vocabulary> than you thought!

This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>rejoice</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>joy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>delight</vocabulary>. You rejoice because there are lots of reasons for your <vocabulary>glee</vocabulary>.
What happens when you <kanji>take along</kanji> a <kanji>day</kanji>? It becomes <vocabulary>every day</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>take along</kanji> some things that are <kanji>related</kanji>, you'll be able to understand their <vocabulary>relation</vocabulary> better.
This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>sad</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>sadness</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
If you have <kanji>mixed</kanji> <kanji>blood</kanji>, some people might say you're of <vocabulary>mixed race</vocabulary>. Own it!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>renew</kanji>, and this verb's meaning isn't far off. What do you do if you renew something, usually to make it better? You're going <vocabulary>to change something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to revise something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to correct something</vocabulary>. This verb is transitive, so it takes a direct object.

改める is a formal word for when you're actively make changes or improvements, like fixing a mistake or reforming a system. You might also use it when you decide to change your behavior or update your way of doing something.
<kanji>Drink</kanji> <kanji>alcohol</kanji> is <vocabulary>drinking alcohol</vocabulary>, or just <vocabulary>drinking</vocabulary>. This always refers to alcohol though.
An <kanji>insect</kanji> <kanji>insect</kanji> is... you guessed it! An <vocabulary>insect</vocabulary>.
When you're <kanji>hold</kanji>ing food and <kanji>return</kanji>ing home with it, you're likely getting <vocabulary>takeout</vocabulary>.
Remember how 一昨日 means "day before last"? Similarly, <kanji>one</kanji> year <kanji>previous</kanji> to that <kanji>year</kanji> is the <vocabulary>year before last</vocabulary>.

You have <kanji>pass through</kanji>, so this is <vocabulary>to pass through</vocabulary>.

This word has a bunch of different meanings, and translations will vary depending on context. In short, it's mostly used figuratively to mean that something, like communication, is passing or coming through successfully. Have a look at our common word combinations and context sentences for some example usages!

A <kanji>stream</kanji> containing <kanji>stone</kanji>s is like… the most natural thing ever. It's just <vocabulary>as expected</vocabulary>. 

Note that you'll encounter this being written in kana as well, but the meaning is the same.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Occur At The Same Time

meaning_mnemonic:
If you remember 重ねる, then you'll recognize this as the intransitive version of that verb. Literally, this means <vocabulary>to be piled up</vocabulary>, but it's often used to mean <vocabulary>to coincide</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to overlap</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to accumulate</vocabulary>.

As is often our recommendation for more complicated or hard-to-translate words like this one, check out our common word combinations and context sentences to see how this word is used!

If something happens in the <kanji>east</kanji>, <kanji>west</kanji>, <kanji>south</kanji>, and <kanji>north</kanji>, then it's happening in <vocabulary>all directions</vocabulary>. What other directions are there? That's literally all of them.

This word usually appears in expressions like 東西南北を見る (to look in all directions). But it can also be used more literally to mean <vocabulary>east west south north</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>cardinal directions</vocabulary>.
